name: Lanthanum
Analysis: The atomic radius decreases from lanthanum to lutetium due to lanthanide contraction, caused by poor shielding of 4f electrons, which increases nuclear attraction. While a continuous decrease is expected, the covalent radii of samarium-europium, dysprosium-holmium, and ytterbium-lutetium are similar, and erbium to thulium shows a higher value. These discrepancies may arise from using covalent rather than metallic radii and variations in measurement methods.

name: Cerium
Analysis: There is a slight decrease in the atomic radius from lanthanum to cerium. This is due to the increase in the number of electrons in the orbitals of 4f (antepenultimate shell) subshell. The 4f subshell has a poor shielding effect due to which the outershell electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus decreasing the atomic radius from lanthanum to cerium. This is known as the lanthanide contraction.

name: Samarium
Analysis: There is a slight decrease in the atomic radius from promethium to samarium. This is due to the increase in the number of electrons in the orbitals of 4f (antepenultimate shell) subshell. The 4f subshell has a poor shielding effect due to which the outershell electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus decreasing the atomic radius from promethium to samarium. This is known as the lanthanide contraction.

name: Europium
Analysis: There should be decrease in the atomic radius from samarium to europium due to lanthanide contraction. However, the covalent radius of dsamarium and europium is similar. The discrepancy in the data could be due to the consideration of covalent radius and not the metallic radius and also on the way the covalent radius is calculated.

name: Gadolinium
Analysis: There is a slight decrease in the atomic radius from europium to gadolinium. This is due to the increase in the number of electrons in the orbitals of 4f (antepenultimate shell) subshell. The 4f subshell has a poor shielding effect due to which the outershell electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus decreasing the atomic radius from lanthanum to lutetium. This is known as the lanthanide contraction.

name: Holmium

However, the covalent radius of dysprosium and holmium is same. The discrepancy in the data could be due to the consideration of covalent radius and not the metallic radius and also on the way the covalent radius is calculated.

name: Erbium
Analysis: There is a decrease in the atomic radius from holmium to erbium. This is due to the increase in the number of electrons in the orbitals of 4f (antepenultimate shell) subshell. The 4f subshell has a poor shielding effect due to which the outershell electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus decreasing the atomic radius from holmium to erbium. name: Thulium
Analysis: There should be a decrease in the atomic radius from erbium to thulium due to lanthanide contration caused by poor shielding effect of 4f orbitals. However, covalent radius of thulium is 190 pm while that of erbium is 189 pm. This could also be due to the ay covalent radius is calculated. It would have been better to consider the metallic radius for the analysis. Unfortunately, we could not find the metallic radius data for lanthanides. However, the overall trend remains the same.

name: Ytterbium
Analysis: There is a decrease in the atomic radius from thulium to ytterbium. This is due to the increase in the number of electrons in the orbitals of 4f (antepenultimate shell) subshell. name: Lutetium
Analysis: There should be a decrease in the atomic radius from ytterbium to lutetium due to lanthanide contraction caused by poor shielding effect of 4f orbitals. However, covalent radius of ytterbium and lutetium is same i.e. 187 pm. This could be due to the consideration of the covalent radius and also the way it is calculated. Thus, it would have been better to consider the metallic radius for the analysis. Unfortunately, we could not find the metallic radius data for lanthanides. However, the overall trend remains the same.

name: Actinium
Analysis:
Actinium has a higher atomic radius than lutetium due to an increase in the number of shells (6 to 7). The atomic radius then decreases from actinium to curium due to actinide contraction, caused by poor shielding of 5f electrons, which enhances nuclear attraction. Thorium, with two 6d electrons and a 7th shell, also experiences a radius decrease due to poor shielding effect of electrons in d-orbitals. From protactinium onward, additional 5f electrons further reduce the radius due to their poor shielding effect. 

The atomic radius should decrease from curium to lawrencium due to actinide contraction. However, for berkelium to lawrencium, only Van der Waals radii are available in some databases, which are larger than covalent or metallic radii. However, actinide contraction should cause a decrease from curium to berkelium. Covalent radii from the RSC website indicate: berkelium (168 pm), californium (168 pm), einsteinium (165 pm), fermium (167 pm), mendelevium (173 pm), nobelium (176 pm), and lawrencium (161 pm).

name: Thorium
Analysis: Atomic radius then decreases from actinium to thorium due to actinide contraction. The outermost shell in thorium is 7, the same as that of actinium. There is the presence of 2 electrons in the 6d subshell that has a poor shielding effect that leads to the attraction of the outermost electrons more toward the nucleus. Thus, there is decrease in its atomic radius.

name: Protactinium
Analysis: Atomic radius then decreases from thorium to protactinium due to actinide contraction. The outermost shell in protactinium is 7, the same as that of thorium. There is the presence of 2 electrons in the 5f subshell that has a low shielding effect that leads to the attraction of the outermost electrons more toward the nucleus. Thus, there is decrease in its atomic radius.

name: Uranium
Analysis: From uranium, there is further addition of electrons in the f-orbitals of 5f subshell. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius.

name: Neptunium
Analysis: Atomic radius decreases from uranium to neptunium due to actinide contraction. There are 4 electrons in the f orbitals of 5f subshell. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius.

name: Plutonium
Analysis: Atomic radius decreases from neptunium to plutonium due to actinide contraction. There are 6 electrons in the f orbitals of 5f subshell. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius.

name: Americium
Analysis: Atomic radius decreases from plutonium to amercium due to actinide contraction. There are 7 electrons in the f orbitals of 5f subshell. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius.

name: Curium
Analysis: Atomic radius decreases from amercium to curium due to actinide contraction. There are 7 electrons in the f orbitals of 5f subshell and 1 electron in the 6d orbital. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius.

name: Berkelium
Analysis: It is the Vander radius that is available for berkelium. Vander-Waal radius will always be higher than the covalent or metallic radius. Therefore, atomic radius of berkelium is depicted higher than curium. However, atomic radius should decrease from curium to berkelium due to actinide contraction. There are 9 electrons in the f orbitals of 5f subshell. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius. The database which is used for the analysis does not have covalent radius values of berkelium. However, covalent radius for these elements can be referred from RSC website. The covalent radius of berkelium as per RSC website is 168 pm.

name: Californium
Analysis: It is the Vander radius that is available for californium. Atomic radius should decrease from berkelium to californium due to actinide contraction. There are 10 electrons in the f orbitals of 5f subshell. Since f-orbital has poor shielding effect than d-orbital, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus and thus there should be decrease in its atomic radius. However, there is some discrepancy in the covalent radius data. This could be due to the way the covalent radius is calculated. The database which is used for the analysis does not have covalent radius values of californium. However, covalent radius for these elements can be referred from RSC website. The covalent radius of californium as per RSC website is 168 pm.

Analysis: It is the Vander radius that is available from einsteinium. Atomic radius decrease from californium to einsteinium due to actinide contraction. name: Lawrencium
Analysis: It is the Vander radius that is available from lawrencium. Atomic radius decreases from nobelium to lawrencium due to actinide contraction. Since f-orbital and d-orbital has poor shielding effect, therefore outermost electrons are more attracted towards the nucleus thereby decreasing its atomic radius.
